items.text: I believe that traditions and customs should be preserved and respected.
items.rationale: Valuing tradition is a core component of Conservation, reflecting conformity and maintenance of the status quo.

items.text: It is important to me to live in a safe and secure environment.
items.rationale: Security—both personal and societal—is a defining value within the Conservation dimension.

items.text: I think people should follow the rules even when no one is watching.
items.rationale: Conformity to social norms and rules is central to Conservation values.

items.text: I feel uncomfortable when people challenge long-standing social norms.
items.rationale: Resistance to change and preference for established norms directly reflects Conservation.

items.text: Respecting elders and authority figures is something I was raised to value and still hold dear.
items.rationale: Deference to authority and respect for hierarchy are hallmarks of Conservation values.

items.text: I would describe myself as someone who values stability over excitement.
items.rationale: Preferring stability directly contrasts with Openness to Change and anchors in Conservation.

items.text: National security and public order are among the most important priorities for any society.
items.rationale: Emphasis on societal security is a core Conservation value.

items.text: I try to behave properly and avoid doing anything that others would say is wrong.
items.rationale: Conformity—restraining actions that might violate social expectations—is central to Conservation.

items.text: Religious or cultural rituals give my life a sense of meaning and continuity.
items.rationale: Tradition, including religious observance and cultural rituals, is a defining Conservation value.

items.text: I prefer a predictable daily routine over a life full of surprises.
items.rationale: Preference for predictability reflects the security and stability aspects of Conservation.

items.text: It bothers me when people are disrespectful toward symbols of our heritage, like flags or monuments.
items.rationale: Attachment to cultural symbols reflects tradition and conformity values within Conservation.

items.text: I believe that being polite and well-mannered is one of the most important qualities a person can have.
items.rationale: Valuing politeness and manners reflects conformity to social expectations, a Conservation value.

items.text: I sometimes worry that society is changing too fast and losing what made it strong.
items.rationale: While clearly reflecting Conservation concerns, the worry component could also reflect general anxiety rather than a pure value orientation.

items.text: Family obligations should come before personal desires.
items.rationale: Prioritizing family duty reflects Conservation conformity and tradition, but could also reflect Self-Transcendence benevolence toward close others.

items.text: I think it's important to be loyal to the groups I belong to, even if I sometimes disagree with them.
items.rationale: Group loyalty reflects Conservation conformity, but loyalty and concern for in-group welfare also overlaps with Self-Transcendence benevolence.

items.text: I am always looking for new experiences that challenge my perspective on life.
items.rationale: Seeking novel, perspective-challenging experiences is the essence of stimulation and self-direction within Openness to Change.

items.text: Making my own decisions, even if they turn out to be wrong, is more important to me than following someone else's advice.
items.rationale: Self-direction—independent thought and action—is a core Openness to Change value.

items.text: I get restless if my life becomes too routine and predictable.
items.rationale: Need for stimulation and variety directly reflects Openness to Change.

items.text: I enjoy exploring unfamiliar places without a detailed plan.
items.rationale: Spontaneous exploration reflects both stimulation-seeking and self-direction, core Openness to Change values.

items.text: I value my freedom to choose my own path in life above almost everything else.
items.rationale: Autonomy and freedom of choice are defining features of self-direction within Openness to Change.

items.text: People who know me would say I thrive on variety and change.
items.rationale: Third-person behavioral description of stimulation-seeking, a core Openness to Change value.

items.text: I would rather create my own way of doing things than follow established methods.
items.rationale: Preference for independent, creative approaches reflects self-direction within Openness to Change.

items.text: A life without adventure and risk would feel empty to me.
items.rationale: Valuing adventure and risk-taking reflects the stimulation component of Openness to Change.

items.text: I question rules and conventions that don't seem to have a good reason behind them.
items.rationale: Questioning authority and conventions reflects self-direction and independent thinking.

items.text: I feel most alive when I'm doing something I've never done before.
items.rationale: Novelty-seeking and stimulation are core motivational drivers of Openness to Change.

items.text: Being curious and asking questions is more important than having all the answers.
items.rationale: Intellectual curiosity and valuing exploration over certainty reflect self-direction.

items.text: I resist being told what to do, even by people who have more experience than I do.
items.rationale: Resistance to external control and emphasis on autonomy are central to self-direction.

items.text: I enjoy learning about cultures and worldviews that are very different from my own.
items.rationale: While curiosity about diverse cultures reflects self-direction and stimulation, it also overlaps with universalism in Self-Transcendence.

items.text: I like to think of creative solutions to problems rather than relying on what has worked before.
items.rationale: Creativity and innovation reflect self-direction, though in achievement contexts this could also relate to Self-Enhancement.

items.text: I enjoy taking on daring physical challenges like extreme sports or wilderness adventures.
items.rationale: While thrill-seeking reflects stimulation (Openness to Change), the competitive and mastery aspects could also reflect achievement within Self-Enhancement.

items.text: Being successful and recognized for my accomplishments is extremely important to me.
items.rationale: Achievement and social recognition are core motivational values within Self-Enhancement.

items.text: I want to be the best at whatever I do, and I'm willing to work harder than anyone else to get there.
items.rationale: Competitive drive and striving for personal excellence are hallmarks of achievement within Self-Enhancement.

items.text: Having influence over other people and the ability to direct outcomes is something I actively seek.
items.rationale: Seeking power and influence over others is a defining value of Self-Enhancement.

items.text: I believe that people who work the hardest deserve the greatest rewards, and I intend to be one of them.
items.rationale: Meritocratic beliefs tied to personal ambition reflect achievement motivation within Self-Enhancement.

items.text: I enjoy being in charge and making decisions that others follow.
items.rationale: Desire for authority and leadership reflects the power component of Self-Enhancement.

items.text: Financial wealth and material success are important markers of a life well lived.
items.rationale: Valuing wealth and material possessions reflects power values within Self-Enhancement.

items.text: I compare myself to others frequently and feel motivated when I come out ahead.
items.rationale: Social comparison and competitive motivation are characteristic of Self-Enhancement achievement and power values.

items.text: I want people to admire me for what I have accomplished.
items.rationale: Desire for admiration and social prestige reflects achievement and power within Self-Enhancement.

items.text: When I walk into a room, I like to feel that I command respect.
items.rationale: Desire for dominance and social status reflects the power component of Self-Enhancement.

items.text: I set ambitious goals for myself and feel dissatisfied until I reach them.
items.rationale: High personal ambition and goal-driven behavior reflect achievement motivation in Self-Enhancement.

items.text: It is important to me to demonstrate my competence so that others take me seriously.
items.rationale: Demonstrating competence for social recognition combines achievement and power values.

items.text: I would rather lead a project than be a team member, because I trust my own judgment most.
items.rationale: Preference for leadership and confidence in one's own superiority reflect power and achievement.

items.text: I take pride in owning high-quality, prestigious things that reflect my success.
items.rationale: Valuing prestigious possessions reflects power/wealth, though pride in quality could also reflect a general aesthetic preference.

items.text: I push myself to excel because I genuinely enjoy mastering difficult challenges.
items.rationale: Mastery motivation reflects achievement, but intrinsic enjoyment of challenge could also reflect self-direction within Openness to Change.

items.text: I believe strong leaders are essential, and I aspire to be one who guides my community effectively.
items.rationale: While leadership aspiration reflects Self-Enhancement power, the community-oriented framing introduces Self-Transcendence benevolence.

items.text: I believe that all people, regardless of background, deserve to be treated with equal dignity and respect.
items.rationale: Universal equality and respect for all people are core universalism values within Self-Transcendence.

items.text: Protecting the natural environment is a moral responsibility, not just a practical concern.
items.rationale: Environmental concern framed as moral duty reflects universalism within Self-Transcendence.

items.text: I go out of my way to help people who are struggling, even if they are strangers.
items.rationale: Prosocial behavior toward strangers reflects both benevolence and universalism, core Self-Transcendence values.

items.text: Social justice and reducing inequality are causes I feel deeply passionate about.
items.rationale: Commitment to social justice and equality is a defining universalism value within Self-Transcendence.

items.text: The welfare of others matters to me as much as my own well-being.
items.rationale: Prioritizing others' welfare equally to one's own reflects the self-transcendent orientation of benevolence and universalism.

items.text: I feel a deep sense of connection to all living things on this planet.
items.rationale: Feeling connected to all life reflects universalism and broad ecological concern within Self-Transcendence.

items.text: Forgiving people who have wronged me is important because I believe in giving others a second chance.
items.rationale: Forgiveness and tolerance reflect benevolence and universalism values.

items.text: I would accept a lower salary to work for an organization that makes a positive difference in the world.
items.rationale: Sacrificing personal gain for broader social good directly reflects Self-Transcendence over Self-Enhancement.

items.text: When I see suffering in the world, I feel personally compelled to do something about it.
items.rationale: Empathic concern and motivation to alleviate suffering reflect benevolence and universalism.

items.text: I believe that listening to and understanding people who are different from me makes me a better person.
items.rationale: Valuing understanding across differences reflects universalism and tolerance within Self-Transcendence.

items.text: Being honest and trustworthy in my relationships is one of my highest priorities.
items.rationale: Honesty and trustworthiness in close relationships are core benevolence values within Self-Transcendence.

items.text: I think wealthy nations have a moral obligation to help poorer countries develop and prosper.
items.rationale: Concern for global equity and international welfare reflects universalism within Self-Transcendence.

items.text: I find deep satisfaction in volunteering my time for causes that benefit my local community.
items.rationale: Community volunteering reflects benevolence, but the local focus and personal satisfaction could also relate to Conservation's emphasis on in-group welfare.

items.text: I try to be a loyal and dependable friend because the people close to me deserve my best.
items.rationale: Loyalty and dependability toward close others reflect benevolence, but loyalty to in-group also overlaps with Conservation conformity values.

items.text: I believe we should preserve cultural traditions because they give diverse communities a sense of identity and belonging.
items.rationale: Valuing cultural preservation for the sake of diverse communities reflects universalism tolerance, but the emphasis on tradition preservation could map to Conservation.
